competitor_shortcomings.materials: Farm Rio uses 100% polyester that pills and loses shape. Budget brands use cheap synthetics that compress into flat, cold layers. Most jackets at this price point sacrifice durability for cost.
competitor_shortcomings.comfort: Farm Rio sizing runs 2 sizes too big (size 4/6 wearing XXS). Cheap puffers are stiff, itchy, and ill-fitting. Many trap heat without breathability, making you sweat then freeze.
competitor_shortcomings.durability: Budget jackets snag, pill, and lose shape after one season. Farm Rio has quality control issues - defective items, poor sewing, missing buttons. Cheap materials compress and lose insulation capacity fast.
competitor_shortcomings.functionality: Farm Rio puffers at $539 are fashion-first, not performance - just for Instagram poses, not actual skiing. Budget options aren't warm enough for real mountain conditions. Shell materials aren't waterproof or windproof.
competitor_shortcomings.lifestyle_limits: Fashion puffers can't handle backcountry conditions. Cheap jackets lack breathability for active skiing. Non-versatile designs only work on slopes, not for apr√®s-ski or city wear.
competitor_shortcomings.psychological: Wearing a $500+ jacket creates anxiety about damaging it. Looking like you're wearing a rental jacket kills confidence. Choosing between style and function feels like losing either way.
